</div>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports) and (2)&nbsp;have been subject to such filing requirements for the past 90 days. Yes&nbsp;<font face="Wingdings 2">&#084;</font>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;<font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of July 15, 2004, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 237,227,847 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of July 15, 2004, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding 132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held, beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG Power LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC are wholly-owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction H(1) (a) and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction H.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether each registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Exchange Act).</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Forward'>FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Except for the historical information contained herein, certain of the matters discussed in this report constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#39;s beliefs, as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to management. When used herein, the words &ldquo;will&rdquo;, &ldquo;anticipate&rdquo;, &ldquo;intend&rdquo;, &ldquo;estimate&rdquo;, &ldquo;believe&rdquo;, &ldquo;expect&rdquo;, &ldquo;plan&rdquo;, &ldquo;hypothetical&rdquo;, &ldquo;potential&rdquo;, &ldquo;forecast&rdquo;, &ldquo;projections&rdquo;, variations of such words
and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. The following review of factors should not be construed as exhaustive.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements include, among others, the following:</font></p>

<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>substandard operating performance or cash flow from investments falling below projected levels, adversely impacting the ability to service its debt;</font></td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td width=24pt align=left valign=top nowrap></td>
<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>deteriorating credit of lessees and their ability to adequately service lease rentals; </font><font color=#000000>and</font></td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td width=24pt align=left valign=top nowrap></td>
<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>ability to realize tax benefits</font><font color=#000000>.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Consequently, all of the forward-looking statements made in this report are qualified by these cautionary statements and each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings cannot assure you that the results or developments anticipated by management will be realized, or even if realized, will have the expected consequences to, or effects on PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings or their respective business prospects, financial condition or results of operations. Undue reliance should not be placed on these forward-looking statements in making any investment decision. Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expressly disclaim any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or are anticipated
to occur or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section&nbsp;21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</font></p>

<PAGE>

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 1'>Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Organization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has four principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility company engaged principally in the transmission and distribution of electric energy and natural gas service in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also owns PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding), a bankruptcy remote entity established for the purpose of purchasing intangible transition property and issuing transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is a multi-regional wholesale energy supply business that utilizes energy trading to comprehensively manage its portfolio of electric generation assets, gas supply and storage contracts and electric and natural gas supply obligations. Power has three principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the day-to-day management of the portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T are subject to regulation by </font><font color=#000000>the</font><font color=#000000> FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings has two principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global LLC (Global), which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation and distribution of energy, including independent power production facilities and electric distribution companies; and PSEG Resources LLC (Resources), which has primarily invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy Holdings also owns Enterprise Group Development Corporation (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management business. During the third quarter of 2003, Energy Holdings completed the sale of PSEG Energy Technologies Inc. (Energy Technologies)</font><font color=#000000>. For additional information relating to Energy Technologies, see Note 4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides management and administrative services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, legal, communications, human resources, information technology, treasury and financial, investor relations, stockholder services, real estate, environmental, health and safety, insurance, risk management, tax, library and information services, security, corporate secretarial and certain planning, budgeting and forecasting services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the</font></p>
<p align=center>16</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>cost of work performed and services provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Basis of Presentation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q. Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction with, and update and supplement matters discussed in, </font><font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39;</font><font color=#000000> respective </font><font color=#000000>Annual Report on Form 10-K </font><font color=#000000>for
the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003</font><font color=#000000> and Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments, which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in the </font><font color=#000000>Annual Report on Form 10-K </font><font color=#000000>for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003</font><font color=#000000>. Certain reclassifications of prior period data have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Pension and Other Postemployment Benefits (OPEB)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG and its participating affiliates&#39; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria.</font></p>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><small><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></small></font></p>
</div>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(A) Other amounts relate to costs at Services.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Stock Compensation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the second quarter of 2004, 574,200 non-qualified stock options to purchase PSEG common stock were granted to certain key employees.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Also during the second quarter of 2004, 94,400 shares of restricted stock were granted under the 2004 Long Term Incentive Plan (LTIP) to certain key executives. These shares are subject to restrictions on transfer and subject to risk of forfeiture until vested by continued employment. The shares vest on a staggered schedule beginning on December 31, 2004, and become fully vested on December 31, 2006. The unearned compensation related to these restricted stock grants as of June 30, 2004 is approximately $4 million and is included in Retained Earnings on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, 94,400 performance units were granted to certain key executives, which provide for payment in shares of PSEG common stock within 45 days of January 1, 2007 based on achievement of certain financial goals. The performance units are credited with dividend equivalents in an amount equal to dividends paid on PSEG common stock up until January 1, 2007. As of June 30, 2004, approximately 95,697 performance units were outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG applies Accounting Principles Board </font><font color=#000000>(APB)</font><font color=#000000> Opinion No. 25, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&rdquo; and related interpretations in accounting for stock-based compensation plans. Accordingly, no compensation has been recognized for the fixed stock option grants since the exercise price of the stock options equaled the market price of the underlying stock on the date of grant. Compensation expense has been recognized for the performance units and dividend equivalents.</font></p>
<p align=center>18</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>See Note 6. Earnings Per Share for further information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On January 1, 2002, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings adopted SFAS No. 142, &ldquo;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&rdquo; (SFAS 142). Under this standard, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings were required to complete an impairment analysis of goodwill. Under SFAS 142, goodwill is a nonamortizable asset subject to an annual review for impairment and an interim review when certain events or changes in circumstances occur.</font></p>
<p align=center>19</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Changes relate to changes in foreign exchange rates.</font></td></tr>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>

<p align=center>20</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) </font></b><b><font color=#000000>Funds</font></b><b></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains
  an independent external trust </font><font color=#000000>to provide for decommissioning
  of its nuclear facilities upon termination of operation. The trust contains
  two separate funds: a qualified fund and a nonqualified fund. Power&#39;s policy
  restricts the trust from investing directly in securities or other obligations
  of PSEG or its affiliates, or its successors or assigns, and from investing
  in securities of any entity owning one or more nuclear power plants. </font><font color=#000000>During
  the second quarter of 2004, Power moved to a yield-based strategy for its nonqualified
  fund to take advantage of a lower tax rate. This change resulted in the realization
  of gains during the second quarter of 2004. See Note&nbsp;11. Other Income and
  Deductions for additional information.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The fair value of the NDT </font><font color=#000000>Funds</font><font color=#000000> was $983 million as of June 30, 2004, including $231 million of Cash and Cash Equivalents.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 2'>Note 2. Restatement of Financial Statements</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Subsequent to the issuance of the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for the quarter ended June 30, 2003 and in preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2003, management determined that the recorded amount of Energy Holdings&#39; investment in RGE was overstated due to a miscalculation of the amount of foreign currency translation adjustments and that certain amounts related to this investment had been erroneously recorded as translation adjustments instead of foreign currency transactions. The impact on previously reported Net Income of PSEG and Energy Holdings of the adjustments related to RGE resulted in an increase of $3 million and $4 million for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2003, respectively. As a result, the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Financial
Statements of PSEG and Energy Holdings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2003 have been restated from the amounts previously reported to reflect the correct amount of foreign currency translation adjustments and to record the effects of foreign currency transactions in earnings rather than as an adjustment to Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss. In addition to the adjustments described above, certain other adjustments, previously considered to be immaterial individually and in the aggregate, were also recorded in the restated Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003. The impact on previously reported Net Income of PSEG and Energy Holdings of these additional adjustments resulted in no change for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2003 and an increase of $4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2003.</font></p>
<p align=center>21</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The amounts as previously reported do not reflect certain reclassifications due to the presentation of Energy Holdings&#39; investment in Carthage Power Company (CPC), a generating facility in Tunisia, as a discontinued operation, as discussed in Note 4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions and the effects of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Interpretation No. (FIN) 46, &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities&rdquo; (FIN 46), as discussed in Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards, and other reclassifications that have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 3'>Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 143, &ldquo;Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (SFAS 143)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Effective January 1, 2003, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each adopted SFAS 143. Under SFAS 143, a company must initially recognize the fair value of a liability for an asset retirement</font></p>
<p align=center>22</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>obligation in the period in which it is incurred and concurrently capitalize an asset retirement cost by increasing the carrying amount of the related long-lived asset by the same amount as the liability. A company is required to subsequently depreciate that asset retirement cost to expense over its useful life. In periods subsequent to the initial measurement, an entity is required to recognize changes in the liability resulting from the passage of time (accretion) or due to revisions to either the timing or the amount of the originally estimated cash flows. Changes in the liability due to accretion are charged to Operation and Maintenance expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations, whereas changes due to the timing or amount of cash flows are adjustments to the carrying amount of the related asset.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a result of adopting SFAS 143, PSEG and Power recorded a Cumulative Effect of a Change in Accounting Principle of $370 million, after-tax, in the first quarter of 2003. Of this after-tax amount, $292 million related to nuclear decommissioning and $78 million related to the reversal of cost of removal liabilities for the fossil units.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FIN 46R and FIN 46</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FASB Interpretation No. 46 (revised December 2003), &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities (VIEs)&rdquo;, (FIN 46R) amends FIN 46 and clarifies the application of Accounting Research Bulletin No. 51, &ldquo;Consolidated Financial Statements&rdquo; to certain entities in which equity investors do not have sufficient equity at risk for the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings adopted the provisions of FIN 46 as of July 1, 2003. There was no effect on Power due to the adoption of these rules. The adoption of FIN 46R did not impact the implementation of FIN 46 (discussed below) by PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings or have any other effects on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The adoption of FIN 46 required PSEG and PSE&amp;G to deconsolidate their capital trusts and Energy Holdings to consolidate its investments in four real estate partnerships. Prior period financial statements have been reclassified for comparability in accordance with FIN 46.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets reflect its equity investment in the capital trusts, which were previously eliminated in consolidation resulting in </font><font color=#000000>recording </font><font color=#000000>equal amounts of additional assets and long-term debt of $36 million as of June 30, 2004 and December 31, 2003. The invested cash was loaned back to PSEG in connection with the issuance of the preferred securities.</font></p>
<p align=center>23</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>

(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG now records interest expense (previously eliminated against the interest income of the trust) instead of preferred securities dividends (since the preferred dividends are paid by the trusts that are no longer consolidated). For PSEG, these amounts totaled $14 million for each of the quarters ended June 30, 2004 and 2003 and $28 million for each of the six-month periods ended June 30, 2004 and 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, PSE&amp;G redeemed its trust preferred securities. For PSE&amp;G, interest expense related to these trusts totaled $3 million and $6 million for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, PSE&amp;G reviewed its Non-Utility Generation (NUG) contracts to determine if the entities involved were VIEs and, if so, if PSE&amp;G was the primary beneficiary. These entities own power plants that sell their output to PSE&amp;G, which PSE&amp;G is contractually obligated to purchase at a variable price that correlates with certain major operating costs of the plants. As a result, PSE&amp;G assumes some of the variability inherent in the operation of these plants.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G attempted to obtain the information necessary to conduct the analysis </font><font color=#000000>of the cash flow variability</font><font color=#000000> required under FIN 46R from two facility owners where PSE&amp;G held a potentially significant variable interest </font><font color=#000000>based on the NUG contracts</font><font color=#000000>. The respective facility owner&#39;s refused to provide the information based on </font><font color=#000000>their respective</font><font color=#000000> belief that the data was competitive and proprietary. As a result, PSE&amp;G is unable to determine whether these entities should be consolidated under FIN 46R and applies the scope exception to FIN 46R that exempts entities that conduct exhaustive efforts to obtain the necessary information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G incurred costs related to these two specific NUG contracts of approximately $1 million and $2 million for the quarters ended June 30, 2004 and 2003, respectively, and approximately </font><font color=#000000>$3</font><font color=#000000> million and $5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2004 and 2003, respectively. PSE&amp;G cannot determine the maximum exposure from these two contracts due to the inability to obtain the necessary information. PSE&amp;G&#39;s exposure relates to the potential for increases in the variable pricing components of the contract </font><font color=#000000>in the event rate recovery is not provided</font><font color=#000000>. PSE&amp;G sells the electricity purchased under all of its NUG contracts at market prices in the PJM Interconnection, L.L.C. (PJM) spot market and recovers
the difference between the variable contract price and market price through the Non-Utility Generation Market Transition Charge (NTC).</font></p>
<p align=center>24</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings evaluated its interests in four real estate partnerships previously accounted for under the equity method of accounting. Management determined that these entities were VIEs and further determined that Energy Holdings was the primary beneficiary and, therefore, was required to consolidate these entities. The current presentation reflects these entities on a fully consolidated basis and all prior periods were restated in accordance with FIN 46.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The consolidation of the real estate partnerships on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets resulted in an increase of approximately $31 million in assets and liabilities. There was no material impact of consolidating the real estate partnerships on Operating Revenues or Operating Expenses.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) Issue No. 03-11, &ldquo;Reporting Realized Gains and Losses on Derivative Instruments That Are Subject to FASB Statement No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, and Not &ldquo;Held for Trading Purposes&rdquo; as Defined in EITF Issue No. 02-3, &ldquo;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities&rdquo; (EITF 03-11)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The EITF has previously discussed the income statement presentation of gains and losses on contracts held for trading purposes in EITF Issue No. 02-3, &ldquo;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities&rdquo; (EITF 02-3). </font><font color=#000000>In its discussion of EITF 03-11,</font><font color=#000000> EITF reached a consensus that gains and losses (realized and unrealized) on all derivative instruments within the scope of </font><font color=#000000>FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;</font><font color=#000000> (SFAS&nbsp;133) should be shown net when recognized in the Consolidated Statement of Operations, whether or not settled physically,
if the derivative instruments are &ldquo;held for trading purposes&rdquo; as defined in EITF 02-3. These rules, which are effective for transactions occurring after September 30, 2003, required PSEG and Power to reduce revenues and costs by approximately $37 million and $82 million for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2004, respectively, since these transactions are required to be recorded as net revenue.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>EITF Issue No. 03-1, &ldquo;The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and Its Application to Certain Investments&rdquo; (EITF 03-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>EITF 03-1 further defines the meaning of an &ldquo;other-than-temporary impairment&rdquo; and its application to debt and equity securities. Impairment occurs when the fair value of a security is less than its cost basis. When such a condition exists, the investor is required to evaluate whether the impairment is other-than-temporary as defined in EITF 03-1. When an impairment is other-than-temporary, the </font><font color=#000000>unrealized loss recorded in </font><font color=#000000>Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income</font><font color=#000000> must be charged to earnings</font><font color=#000000>. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings do not expect any material effects from the adoption of EITF 03-1 on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FASB Staff Position (FSP) 106-2, &ldquo;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003&rdquo; (FSP 106-2)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b><b><font color=#000000>, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b><b></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FSP 106-2 provides guidance on the accounting for the effects of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (Medicare Drug Act) for employers who sponsor postretirement health care plans that provide prescription drug benefits. FSP 106-2 also requires those</font></p>
<p align=center>25</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>employers to provide certain disclosures regarding the effect of the federal subsidy provided by the Medicare Drug Act. The Medicare Drug Act generally permits plan sponsors that provide retiree prescription drug benefits that are &ldquo;actuarially equivalent&rdquo; to the benefits of Medicare Part D to be eligible for a non-taxable federal subsidy. FSP 106-2 is effective for </font><font color=#000000>periods</font><font color=#000000> beginning after June 15, 2004. </font><font color=#000000>Upon adoption of FSP&nbsp;106-2 on July&nbsp;1, 2004, there</font><font color=#000000> was not a material impact on </font><font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s or</font><font color=#000000> Energy </font><font color=#000000>Holdings&#39; condensed consolidated financial statements</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 4'>Note 4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>CPC</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global entered into a definitive purchase and sale agreement related to the sale of its majority interest in CPC, which owns and operates a power plant located in Rades, Tunisia. In May 2004, Global completed the sale of its majority interest in CPC for approximately $43 million in cash. The assets sold consisted primarily of accounts receivable, property, plant and equipment and other assets. The buyer also assumed certain accounts payable, accrued liabilities and debt obligations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $23 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of CPC to its fair value less cost to sell. During the first quarter of 2004, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of CPC&#39;s assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $2 million was required, offsetting the $2 million of income from operations of CPC during the first quarter of 2004. In May 2004, the actual loss on the sale of CPC totaled $18 million. Accordingly, the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2004 include a gain on disposal of $5 million and $3 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of CPC for the quarters and six months ended June 30, 2004 and 2003 are summarized below.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Technologies&#39; Investments</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2002, Energy Holdings adopted a plan to sell its heating, ventilating and air conditioning (HVAC)/mechanical operating companies. The HVAC/mechanical operating companies met the criteria for classification as components of Discontinued Operations. During the first quarter of 2003, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of Energy Technologies&#39; assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $9 million, net of a $3 million tax benefit, was required. The sale of the HVAC/mechanical operating companies and Energy Technologies was complete as of September 30, 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of Energy Technologies for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2003 are as follows:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Dispositions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>LDS</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2004, Global sold a portion of its shares in LDS, in the Lima stock exchange, reducing its ownership from 44% to 38% and received gross proceeds of approximately $28 million. Global realized </font><font color=#000000>an after-tax</font><font color=#000000> gain of approximately $7 million in the quarter ended June 30, 2004 related to the LDS sale recorded in Income from Equity Method Investments on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004, Resources entered an agreement in principle with Midwest Generation LLC, an indirect subsidiary of Edison Mission Energy (EME), to terminate its lease investment in the Collins generating facility in Illinois. In April 2004, Resources closed on the termination of the lease agreement and received gross proceeds of approximately $184 million (approximately $84 million, after-tax) of cash that allowed it to substantially recover its investment in this lease. In connection with the agreement, in the first quarter of 2004, Resources recorded an after-tax charge of approximately $17 million to reduce its carrying value of the Collins lease.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 5'>Note 5. Extraordinary Item</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2002, PSE&amp;G filed an Electric Base Rate Case with the BPU requesting an annual $250 million increase for its electric distribution business. In June 2003, a proposed settlement was filed with the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) who recommended approval of the settlement to the BPU. In July 2003, PSE&amp;G received an oral decision from the BPU approving the proposed settlement with certain modifications. As a result of the oral decision and subsequent summary written order, in the second quarter of 2003, PSE&amp;G recorded certain adjustments in connection with the resolution of various issues relating to the Final Order PSE&amp;G received from the BPU in 1999 relating to PSE&amp;G&#39;s rate unbundling, stranded costs and restructuring proceedings. These amounts include a $30 million pre-tax refund to customers
related to revenues previously collected in rates for nuclear decommissioning. Because this amount reflects the final accounting for PSEG&#39;s generation-related business pursuant to the four-year transition plan mandated by the Final Order, the adjustment has been recorded as an $18 million, after-tax, Extraordinary Item as required under </font><font color=#000000>APB Opinion No. 30, &ldquo;Reporting the Results of</font></p>
<p align=center>27</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Operations&mdash;Reporting the Effects of Disposal of a Segment of a Business, and Extraordinary, Unusual and Infrequently Occurring Events and Transactions&rdquo; (APB 30) and SFAS No. 101, &ldquo;Regulated Enterprises&mdash;Accounting for the Discontinuation of Application of FASB Statement No. 71&rdquo;.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 6'>Note 6. Earnings Per Share</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Diluted Earnings Per Share is calculated by dividing Net Income by the weighted average number of common stock shares outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under PSEG&#39;s equity compensation plans. The following table shows the effect of these stock options on the weighted average number of shares outstanding used in calculating Diluted Earnings Per Share:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=15><b><font color=#000000><small>Six Months Ended June 30,<br>
