<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 16'>Note 16. Subsequent Events</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>TIE</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2004, </font><font color=#000000>Global</font><font color=#000000> notified TECO of its intent to convert a fractional amount of its preferred equity into common equity in TIE on July&nbsp;1, 2004, and thereby gain majority control of the TIE</font></p>
<p align=center>51</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>partnership. Subsequent to this notification, TECO indicated a desire to transfer its entire interest in TIE to </font><font color=#000000>Global</font><font color=#000000>. On July&nbsp;27, 2004, Global signed an agreement to acquire all of TECO&#39;s interests in TIE, for a nominal value. With this purchase, which is subject to regulatory approvals, Global will own 100% of TIE. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;14. Related-Party Transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Changes in Capitalization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2004, Energy Holdings redeemed $75 million of preference units owned by PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=center>52</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='mda'>ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT&#39;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL</a><br>
CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Following are the significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2003 Annual Report on Form 10-K and Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 affecting the consolidated financial condition and the results of operations. This discussion refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) and should be read in conjunction with such Statements and Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power), and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As discussed in Note 2. Restatement of Financial Statements of the Notes, the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements of PSEG and Energy Holdings have been restated for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003. The following discussion gives effect to this restatement.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Overview'>OVERVIEW</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are PSE&amp;G, Power and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global LLC (Global) and PSEG Resources LLC (Resources).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Based on results of the second quarter of 2004 and expectations for the balance of the year, PSEG has revised its original projections for 2004 Income from Continuing Operations from a range of $3.60 to $3.80 per share to a range of </font><font color=#000000>$3.15</font><font color=#000000> to </font><font color=#000000>$3.35</font><font color=#000000> per share. The reduction in the earnings projection was primarily due to lower than expected earnings from Power, discussed below. PSEG </font><font color=#000000>is preparing</font><font color=#000000> its annual business </font><font color=#000000>plan</font><font color=#000000> for 2005 </font><font color=#000000>and no longer expects 2005 earnings to be flat to its original 2004 guidance of $3.60 to $3.80 per share. PSEG</font><font color=#000000> cannot provide any
guidance beyond 2004 until </font><font color=#000000>its planning</font><font color=#000000> process is completed. </font><font color=#000000>However, it appears that several 2004 factors will carry over into 2005, including higher nuclear and fossil operations and maintenance costs, more modest revenue from trading activities and ongoing impacts from the transformer outage, discussed below.</font><font color=#000000> Given the volatility of the power sector, the competitiveness of the wholesale markets, current historically low capacity prices and the uncertainty of investment opportunities, it has become more difficult to accurately predict future results.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a result
  of the reduced earnings projections, combined with the timing of certain tax
  benefits, PSEG anticipates that it will have cash requirements, after dividends
  and capital expenditures, of approximately $100 million for
  2004, not including net proceeds from asset sales. PSEG expects operating cash
  flows beyond 2004 to be sufficient to fund its investments and meet dividend
  requirements and may employ any excess cash to reduce debt, invest in its businesses,
  increase dividends or repurchase stock over the long-term.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors has approved a quarterly dividend rate of $0.55 per share for the first three quarters of 2004. This reflects an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.20 per share. Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 totaled approximately $130 million and $260 million, respectively. PSEG will continue to evaluate its dividend payments and </font><font color=#000000>will consider</font><font color=#000000> modest increases</font><font color=#000000> in the future.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Beginning on June&nbsp;1, 2004, a greater portion of Power&#39;s Operating Revenues </font><font color=#000000>are</font><font color=#000000> earned through </font><font color=#000000>load serving supply</font><font color=#000000> contracts with its affiliate, PSE&amp;G. Power&#39;s Operating Revenues related to the contracts are eliminated against the corresponding Energy Costs at PSE&amp;G when preparing PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. As a result, there will be a decrease in PSEG&#39;s future Operating Revenues and Energy Costs as compared to current levels.</font></p>
<p align=center>53</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) for its distribution operations and by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for its electric transmission and wholesale sales operations. As such, the earnings of PSE&amp;G are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies. In February 2004, the BPU approved the results of the New Jersey&#39;s third annual basic generation service (BGS) auction process and PSE&amp;G successfully secured contracts to provide the electricity requirements for its customer&#39;s needs. The cost of energy supply, for both gas and electricity, is passed through from PSE&amp;G to its customers.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has revised its expected Income from Continuing Operations for 2004 to range from $340 million to $360 million, a $20 million increase over its original projections primarily due to increased sales volumes due to electric load growth in its territory and favorable weather conditions compared to the original assumptions used in PSE&amp;G&#39;s projections. PSE&amp;G&#39;s future success will be dependent, in part, on its ability to maintain a reasonable rate of return under its regulated rate structure, continue cost containment initiatives and continue recovery of its regulatory assets. PSE&amp;G&#39;s focus is to maintain system reliability and safety levels while it enhances the operations of its electric and gas transmission and distribution systems.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that is focused on a generation market extending from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana (Super Region). Power&#39;s principal operating subsidiaries, PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil), PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T) are regulated by FERC. Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to balance its generating capacity, fuel requirements and supply obligations through integrated energy marketing and trading and enhance its ability to produce low cost energy through efficient nuclear operations and pursue modest growth in the Super Region based on market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has revised its expected Income from Continuing Operations for 2004 from a range of $400 million to $450 million to a range of $300 million to </font><font color=#000000>$350</font><font color=#000000> million primarily due to a series of factors related to its nuclear and fossil operations, impacts due to recent market pricing and electric transmission congestion, including replacement power costs, and results of its trading operations. With respect to nuclear operations, </font><font color=#000000>Power&#39;s </font><font color=#000000>results</font><font color=#000000> were negatively impacted by unanticipated and extended outages at its Hope Creek and Salem stations. These outages were the result of necessary repair and maintenance work, which is expected to improve long-term operating performance. For the
</font><font color=#000000>quarter </font><font color=#000000>and six month periods ended June&nbsp;30</font><font color=#000000>, 2004, the aggregate capacity factor of Power&#39;s nuclear generating stations was approximately 77% </font><font color=#000000>and 85%, respectively</font><font color=#000000>, as compared to </font><font color=#000000>planning assumptions of approximately</font><font color=#000000> 89% </font><font color=#000000>and 93%</font><font color=#000000>, respectively. For the entire year, Power anticipates a capacity factor of 86%</font><font color=#000000>. In addition, Power&#39;s fossil operations were negatively impacted by unanticipated outages at its Hudson station and extended outages at its Mercer station. The Mercer extension was due to a delay in the return to service following the installation of new technology to reduce NO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>x</sub></small></font><font
color=#000000> emissions. The outages referenced above have caused an increase of approximately $9 million in Operation and Maintenance expenses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The outages
  mainly occurred in April and May during warmer weather periods that </font><font color=#000000>led
  to</font><font color=#000000> increased prices and increased electric demand
  volumes. During the second quarter of 2004, </font><font color=#000000>market</font><font color=#000000>
  prices were over $42 per MWh, more than 20% higher than the comparable period
  in 2003. These outages required the purchase of replacement power in the market
  to satisfy Power&#39;s contracted obligations to serve load and supply power,
  which increased Energy Costs by approximately $65 million for the quarter, including
  approximately </font><font color=#000000>$20</font><font color=#000000> million
  for congestion costs. Congestion costs result from the transmission system being
  unable to use available lower-cost power due to physical constraints on the
  system. During much of this period, the price of replacement power was significantly
  impacted by higher than expected congestion costs. Power believes that a large
  portion of the congestion costs was related to the derating of an electric transformer
  </font><font color=#000000>maintained by PSE&amp;G, which is</font><font color=#000000>
  in the PJM Interconnection, L.L.C. (PJM) system, </font><font color=#000000>and
  is being replaced, </font><font color=#000000>with an</font><font color=#000000>
  expected </font><font color=#000000>return to</font><font color=#000000> service
  in </font><font color=#000000>June</font><font color=#000000> 2005 as posted
  on the PJM OASIS website.</font></p>
<p align=center>54</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>As a result, the cost to serve load in the area
  around the transformer being replaced has increased disproportionally to the
  revenues earned from Power's generating facilities. Further impacting forecasted
  2004 results for Power is the reduction in the year-to-date trading results
  versus expectations</font><font color=#000000>. Year-to-date events, coupled
  with the anticipated expansion of the Hope Creek refueling outage scheduled
  for later this year, have contributed to the revision in expected Income from
  Continuing Operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Waterford
  and Lawrenceburg facilities in the Midwest have experienced a very low capacity
  factor due to oversupply in the market, and therefore have only provided modest
  revenue. Power cannot predict when these market conditions will improve.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Some of
  the issues discussed above are expected to carry over into 2005 and beyond.</font><font color=#000000>
  </font><font color=#000000>Power&#39;s future success as an energy provider
  depends, in part, on its ability to meet its obligations under its full requirements
  contracts efficiently and profitably and the efficient operation of its low-cost
  nuclear and coal generation facilities. Power&#39;s ability to meet its forecasts
  will continue to be impacted by low capacity prices due to the oversupply of
  electric generation capacity and the resulting competition combined with volatile
  prices and conditions in energy and fuel markets, including increasing commodity
  and transportation costs. Events such as those experienced in the first half
  of the year will have a negative impact on Power&#39;s results of operations.
  The amounts related to the outages discussed above may not be indicative of
  any future costs, which could be higher or lower depending upon various factors,
  including seasonality, availability of alternate generation and sources, congestion,
  demand, fuel prices and hedging activities.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s objective is to enter into load serving supply contracts and trading positions for at least 75% of its anticipated output over an 18-month to 24-month horizon. To achieve its objective, Power entered into 12-month and 36-month contracts to directly supply PSE&amp;G and other New Jersey electric distribution companies (EDCs) with a portion of their BGS requirements through the BGS auction process. In addition to these contracts, Power has entered into firm supply contracts with EDCs in Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Maryland and other firm sales and trading positions and commitments. Power expects to take advantage of similar opportunities elsewhere in the Super Region.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings, through Global, owns and operates generation and distribution facilities in international and U.S. markets. The generation plants sell power under long-term agreements, as well as on a merchant basis, while the distribution companies are rate-regulated enterprises. Through Resources, Energy Holdings invests in energy-related financial transactions, including leveraged leases, which are designed to produce predictable earnings and cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings continues to limit its capital spending during 2004 to existing contractual commitments and to place an emphasis on improved performance of existing businesses. Energy Holdings continues to expect Income from Continuing Operations for 2004 to range from $130 million to $150 million. Global&#39;s success depends, in part, on its ability to mitigate risks presented by its international strategy, such as the economic, regulatory and political conditions in certain countries where Global has investments. Global may restructure certain projects and is reviewing its portfolio, seeking to opportunistically monetize investments that may no longer have a strategic fit. In keeping with this strategy, during the second quarter of 2004, Global completed the sale of its investment in Carthage Power Company (CPC), a generating
facility in Rades, Tunisia and sold a portion of its shares in Luz del Sur S.A.A. (LDS), a power distribution company in Peru.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources has shifted its focus from new investments to maintaining its current investment portfolio. Resources&#39; objective is to produce predictable cash flows, earnings and related tax benefits while monitoring credit concerns with respect to certain lessees in its portfolio. </font><font color=#000000>Resources&#39; ability to realize tax benefits associated with its leveraged lease investments </font><font color=#000000>is dependent upon operating gains generated by its affiliates</font><font color=#000000>.</font><font color=#000000> In April 2004, Resources closed on the termination of its lease with Edison Mission Energy (EME) in the Collins generating facility. This transaction strengthened the credit quality of Resources&#39; remaining exposure with EME.</font></p>

<p align=center>55</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2004, Energy Holdings has used cash from operations and </font><font color=#000000>proceeds</font><font color=#000000> from the termination of the Collins lease and other asset sales to meet its scheduled debt maturity of $267 million in February 2004, </font><font color=#000000>pay</font><font color=#000000> $300 million of </font><font color=#000000>ordinary unit distributions</font><font color=#000000> and preferred </font><font color=#000000>unit redemptions</font><font color=#000000> to PSEG through July 2004 and for the early retirement of $41 million of debt, reducing its next maturity in 2007 to $309 million.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Results'>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</a></font></b></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>&mdash;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(18</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000>Cumulative Effect of a Change in Accounting<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Principle (E)</font></p></td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include interest on certain financing transactions and certain other administrative and general expenses at Energy Holdings.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include preferred securities dividends requirements for PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings, interest on certain financing transactions and certain other administrative and general expenses at PSEG (as parent company).</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=right><i><font color=#000000>(footnotes continued on next page)</font></i></p>
<p align=center>56</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><i><font color=#000000>(footnotes continued from previous page)</font></i></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Includes Discontinued Operations at Energy Holdings. See Note 4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Relates to charge recorded in the second quarter of 2003 at PSE&amp;G resulting from the decision issued by the BPU in PSE&amp;G&#39;s Electric Base Rate Case. See Note 5. Extraordinary Item of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(E)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Relates to the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (SFAS) No.&nbsp;143, &ldquo;Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;143) in 2003 at Power. See Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $37 million, or $0.19 per share, decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the quarter was primarily due to lower earnings at Power primarily due to the loss of </font><font color=#000000>Market Transition Charge</font><font color=#000000> (MTC) revenues effective August 1, 2003, </font><font color=#000000>at the expiration of the transition period,</font><font color=#000000> and due to higher replacement power, congestion costs and other outage related costs in the current </font><font color=#000000>period, discussed above, partially offset by higher net realized gains from Power&#39;s Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) </font><font color=#000000>Funds</font><font color=#000000> and improved earnings at PSE&amp;G primarily relating to increased electric base rates which were effective August 1, 2003, following
the conclusion of the electric base rate case and seasonality in those rates</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $90 million, or $0.48 per share, decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the six months was primarily due to lower earnings at Power, </font><font color=#000000>for the reasons</font><font color=#000000> discussed above, and lower earnings at Resources, resulting from the termination of the Collins lease, partially offset by improved earnings at PSE&amp;G primarily relating to increased electric base rates and seasonality in those rates.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Included in PSEG&#39;s Net Income for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003 was an after-tax benefit in the amount of $370 million due to the required remeasurement of Power&#39;s nuclear and fossil decommissioning obligations under SFAS&nbsp;143, which was adopted on January&nbsp;1, 2003. In addition, PSE&amp;G recorded an $18 million, after-tax, extraordinary charge in the second quarter of 2003 related to the outcome of its electric base rate case.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Also contributing to the change in Net Income was Energy Holdings&#39; Income from Discontinued Operations of $5 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, as compared to </font><font color=#000000>Loss</font><font color=#000000> from Discontinued Operations of $5 million and $18 </font><font color=#000000>million, </font><font color=#000000>after tax</font><font color=#000000>, for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s results of operations are primarily comprised of the results of operations of its operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, excluding changes related to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated in consolidation. For additional information on intercompany transactions, see Note 14. Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. For a discussion of the causes for the variances at PSEG in the table above, see the discussions for PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings that follow.</font></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>39</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>488</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(125</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(48</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>77</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>160</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has three sources of revenue: commodity revenues from the sales of energy to customers and in the PJM spot market; delivery revenues from the transmission and distribution of energy through its system; and other operating revenues from the provision of various services.</font></p>
<p align=left><i><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commodity</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on commodity sales as the costs are passed through to customers with deferred accounting for the difference between </font><font color=#000000>costs</font><font color=#000000> and </font><font color=#000000>revenues</font><font color=#000000>. Total commodity volumes and revenues are subject to market forces. Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for commercial and industrial customers and annually through the Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) tariff for residential customers. In addition, for residential customers, PSE&amp;G has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted. Gas commodity revenues decreased $50 million and $39 million for the quarter and six months, respectively. Electric commodity prices, which are set in the annual BGS auction
process, increased $20 million and $9 million for the quarter and six months ended June 2004, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><i><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Delivery</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Electric delivery revenues increased $119 million and $174 million for the quarter and six months ended June 2004, respectively. The base rate changes in August 2003 increased revenues by $92 million and $138 million, respectively. The balance of the increase was driven by increased sales of 7% and 5% for the quarter and </font><font color=#000000>six months,</font><font color=#000000> respectively. Less than one percent of the sales increases were weather-related.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Gas delivery revenues decreased $15 million and $38 million for the quarter and six months ended June 2004, respectively. The decreases were the result of lower sales of about 4% in each period primarily due to weather. Heating degree days were 40% and 9% lower for the quarter and six months, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The electric rate changes that took effect in August 2003 generally maintained the overall revenue seasonality for residential customers but significantly increased the summer/winter differential for commercial and industrial customer classes. Increases in residential tariffs were about the same amount year round while virtually all of the increase for the commercial and industrial classes occurs in the summer months. As a result, the impact of the $160 million annual base rate increase was $47 million and $63 million for the quarter and six months ended June 30, 2004, respectively, as compared to the same period in the prior year.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy Costs</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of electric and gas purchases necessary to meet customer load. The difference between energy costs incurred and associated commodity revenues is deferred for future collection or refund to customers.</font></p>
<p align=center>58</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $40 million decrease in electric costs for the quarter was caused by $92 million in lower costs due to lower BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) volumes offset by $52 million in higher prices for BGS and NUG purchases. The $106 million decrease in electric costs for the six months was caused by $193 million in lower costs due to lower BGS and NUG volumes offset by $86 million in higher prices for BGS and NUG purchases.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $55 million decrease in gas costs for the quarter was caused by a combination of a $114 million or 35% decrease in sales volumes offset by a $59 million or 29% increase in gas prices. The $77 million decrease in gas costs for the six months was caused by a combination of a $252 million or 21% decrease in sales volumes offset by $173 million or 19% increase in gas prices.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operation and Maintenance</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The </font><font color=#000000>$34</font><font color=#000000> million increase for the quarter was primarily due to an $18 million reduction in real estate taxes recorded in 2003 and the reversal of a $10 million reserve against a regulatory asset in 2003 that is being recovered. Demand Side Management (DSM) amortization increased $9 million, driven by increased electric expense recovery offset by decreased gas volumes. Offsetting these increases were $4 million in lower labor and fringe benefits, due primarily to better pension fund performance in 2003 resulting in lower 2004 employer contributions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The </font><font color=#000000>$26</font><font color=#000000> million increase for the six months was primarily due to a reduction in real estate taxes of $18 million recorded in 2003 and the reversal of a $10 million reserve against a regulatory asset in 2003 that is being recovered. DSM amortization increased $16 million, driven by increased electric expense recovery offset by decreased gas volumes. Offsetting these increases were $10 million in decreased labor and fringe benefits, $5 million due to lower incentive compensation awards and lower overtime and $5 million due to lower 2004 employer pension contributions. Additional decreases include $7 million in shared services costs due to reduced technology spending and decreased gas bad debt expense of $2 million resulting from decreased sales volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $63 million increase for the quarter was due primarily to a $57 million reduction in amortization of an excess electric distribution depreciation reserve regulatory liability, an $11 million increase in the amortization of various regulatory assets and $3 million due to increased plant in service. These increases were offset by a $7 million decrease from the use of a lower book depreciation rate for electric distribution plants, which took effect in August 2003 following the conclusion of the electric base rate case.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $124 million increase for the six months was due primarily to a $114 million reduction in amortization of an excess electric distribution depreciation reserve regulatory liability, a $17 million increase in the amortization of various regulatory assets and $6 million due to increased plant in service. These increases were offset by a $13 million decrease from the use of a lower book depreciation rate for electric distribution plants, which took effect in August 2003 following the conclusion of the electric base rate case.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $7 million decrease for the six months was due primarily to a decrease in gains on property sales of $11 million, due to lower property sales in 2004. This decrease was offset by a $4 million increase in interest income related to an affiliate loan.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The decreases of $6 million and $7 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, were primarily due to lower interest rates and lower levels of long-term debt outstanding. For the six months, the decrease was partially offset by increased interest associated with carrying charges on certain regulatory assets.</font></p>
<p align=center>59</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increases of $39 million and $77 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, were primarily due to higher pre-tax income in 2004 combined with lower tax benefits primarily attributable to the excess depreciation reserve adjustment in 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Extraordinary Item</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G recorded an $18 million, after-tax, extraordinary charge in the second quarter of 2003 related to the outcome of its electric base rate case. See Note 5. Extraordinary Item </font><font color=#000000>of the Notes</font><font color=#000000> for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $242 million decrease for the quarter was due to decreases of $161 million in generation revenues, $59 million in gas supply revenues and a decrease of $22 million in trading revenues. The $380 million decrease for the six months was due to decreases of $365 million in generation revenues and $43 million in trading revenues, which was offset by a $28 million increase in gas supply revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left><i><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Generation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $161 million decrease in generation revenues for the quarter was primarily due to $64 million in lower revenues due mainly to decreased load being served under the fixed-priced BGS contracts, which was partially offset by revenues from new contracts and higher sales into the various power pools. Also contributing to the decrease for the quarter was the loss of </font><font color=#000000>MTC revenues and NDT revenues effective August 1, 2003, </font><font color=#000000>at the expiration of the transition period</font><font color=#000000>, which amounted to approximately $53 million and $7 million, respectively. In addition, Power adopted Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) Issue No. 03-11, &ldquo;Reporting Realized Gains and Losses on Derivative Instruments That Are Subject to FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133, &ldquo;Accounting
for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, and Not &ldquo;Held for Trading Purposes&rdquo; as Defined in EITF Issue No. 02-3, &ldquo;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities&rdquo; (EITF 03-11), which requires gains and losses (realized and unrealized) on all derivative instruments within the scope of SFAS&nbsp;133 to be shown net when recognized in the </font><font color=#000000>Condensed</font><font color=#000000> Consolidated Statement of Operations, whether or not settled physically, if the derivative instruments are &ldquo;held for trading purposes&rdquo; as defined in EITF 02-3, which is effective on a prospective basis for transactions occurring after September&nbsp;30, 2003. Since prior periods were not restated, the effect of adopting EITF&nbsp;03-11 reduced
Power&#39;s revenues by approximately $37 million for the quarter, with an equal reduction in Energy Costs, as compared to the same period in 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $365 million decrease in generation revenues for the six months was primarily due to $167 million in lower revenues due to decreased load being served under the fixed-priced BGS contracts and the change to seasonal rates, which was partially offset by revenues from new contracts and higher sales into the various power pools. Also contributing to the decrease for the six months was the loss of MTC</font></p>
<p align=center>60</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>and NDT revenues, which amounted to $101 million and $15 million, respectively, and the adoption of EITF 03-11, which reduced revenues by approximately $82 million for the six months.</font></p>
<p align=left><i><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $59 million decrease in gas supply revenues for the quarter was primarily due to decreased sales volumes due to warmer weather in the second quarter in 2004 as compared to the same period in 2003, which was partially offset by higher gas prices under the BGSS contract.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $28 million increase in gas supply revenues for the six months was primarily due to higher gas prices, which was partially offset by decreased sales volumes in the second quarter, as discussed above.</font></p>
<p align=left><i><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The decreases in trading revenues of $22 million and $43 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, were primarily due to market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy Costs</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation, as well as purchased energy in the market and gas purchases to meet Power&#39;s obligation under its BGSS contract with PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $106 million decrease in Energy Costs for the quarter was primarily due to a $68 million decrease in gas supply costs primarily due to decreased volumes due to warmer weather in the second quarter and a $59 million decrease in purchased power due to decreased load being served under the BGS contracts, which was offset by increased replacement power purchases and higher purchased power for new contracts. Also contributing to the decrease for the quarter was a reduction of approximately $37 million related to the adoption of EITF 03-11, as discussed above. Partially offsetting the decreases was higher fuel costs for generation of approximately $59 million, primarily related to higher gas prices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $173 million decrease for the six months was primarily due to a $180 million decrease in purchased power due to decreased load being served under the BGS contracts, which was offset by increased replacement power costs and higher purchased power for new contracts. Also contributing to the decrease for the quarter was a reduction of approximately $82 million related to the adoption of EITF&nbsp;03-11, as discussed above. Partially offsetting these decreases was higher fuel costs for generation of approximately $89 million, primarily related to higher gas prices. Gas supply costs for the six months were relatively flat as increased prices were offset by lower volumes in the second quarter due to warmer weather than the same period in 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operation and Maintenance</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $9 million increase in Operation and Maintenance expenses for the quarter was primarily due to higher maintenance costs </font><font color=#000000>due to the outages at Salem, Hope Creek and Mercer</font><font color=#000000>, higher costs related to the Waterford </font><font color=#000000>facility</font><font color=#000000>, which </font><font color=#000000>was</font><font color=#000000> placed into service in August 2003, </font><font color=#000000>and higher labor and fringe benefits</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $37 million increase in Operation and Maintenance expenses for the six months was primarily due to a $16 million increase related to the </font><font color=#000000>outages at </font><font color=#000000>Hope Creek, </font><font color=#000000>Salem </font><font color=#000000>and </font><font color=#000000>Mercer, </font><font color=#000000>increased co-owner billings of $8 million related to Power&#39;s jointly-owned facilities, </font><font color=#000000>$4&nbsp;million of</font><font color=#000000> higher operation and maintenance costs related to the Waterford </font><font color=#000000>facility and $3&nbsp;million of higher labor and fringe benefits</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million and $8 million increases in Depreciation and Amortization for the quarter and six months, respectively, were primarily due to the Waterford facility being placed into service in August 2003 and the Lawrenceburg facility being placed into service in June 2004.</font></p>
<p align=center>61</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $52 million and $43 million increases in Other Income for the quarter and six months, respectively, were primarily due to increased realized gains and income related to the NDT </font><font color=#000000>Funds</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $12 million increase in Other Deductions for the quarter was primarily due to higher realized losses related to the NDT </font><font color=#000000>Funds</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million increase in Other Deductions for the six months was primarily due to an $8 million write-off of unamortized issuance costs related to the extinguishment of project financing related to Power&#39;s Waterford and Lawrenceburg facilities offset by $6 million in lower realized losses related to the NDT </font><font color=#000000>Funds</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $13 million increase in Interest Expense for the six months was due to new long-term debt financing of $300 million issued in December 2003, the early settlement of an interest rate swap related to the extinguishment of project financing related to Power&#39;s Waterford and Lawrenceburg facilities in the first quarter of 2004 and higher interest related to an affiliate loan. </font><font color=#000000>Partially offsetting these increases was higher </font><font color=#000000>capitalized interest</font><font color=#000000> primarily due to higher rates in 2004 versus 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $52 million and $99 million decreases in Income Tax Expense for the quarter and six months, respectively, were due primarily to lower pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cumulative Effect of a Change in Accounting Principle</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power recorded an after-tax benefit in the amount of $370 million due to the required remeasurement of Power&#39;s nuclear and fossil decommissioning obligations under SFAS&nbsp;143, which was adopted on January&nbsp;1, 2003. See Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The variances in Operating Revenues, Energy Costs, Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Income from Equity Method Investments are primarily attributed to Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Sp. Z o.o. (ELCHO) placing a new generation facility in Poland in service in November 2003 and Dhofar Power Company </font><font color=#000000>S.A.O.C.</font><font color=#000000> (Salalah), a generation facility in Oman, beginning commercial operation in May 2003. The variances for these items also relate to favorable foreign currency exchange rates and higher energy sales volumes at SAESA and the fact that GWF Energy LLC (GWF Energy), which owns three generation facilities in California, was accounted for</font></p>
<p align=center>62</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>under the equity method of accounting in 2004 due to a change in ownership interest as compared to 2003 when GWF Energy was consolidated.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $6 million for the quarter was due to higher </font><font color=#000000>revenues at Global of </font><font color=#000000>$14</font><font color=#000000> million </font><font color=#000000>including</font><font color=#000000> </font><font color=#000000>a $20 million increase from ELCHO, a $6 million increase from Salalah, and a $6 million increase from SAESA, </font><font color=#000000>partially offset by a decrease of $13 million related to GWF Energy. </font><font color=#000000>Offsetting the </font><font color=#000000>increase at Global was</font><font color=#000000> lower revenues at Resources </font><font color=#000000>of $10&nbsp;million primarily</font><font color=#000000> due to a reduction in leveraged lease income of $6 million related to the termination of the Collins lease with Midwest Generation
LLC in April 2004 combined with unrealized losses in Long-Term Investments.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $29 million for the six months was due to higher </font><font color=#000000>revenues at Global of </font><font color=#000000>$52</font><font color=#000000> million </font><font color=#000000>including a</font><font color=#000000> $36 million increase from ELCHO, a $22 million increase from Salalah, and an $18 million increase from SAESA, </font><font color=#000000>partially offset by a decrease of $22 million due to lower revenues related to GWF Energy. </font><font color=#000000>Offsetting</font><font color=#000000> the </font><font color=#000000>increase at Global</font><font color=#000000> was lower revenues at Resources </font><font color=#000000>of $23&nbsp;million, primarily</font><font color=#000000> due to a realized loss of $17 million and a reduction in leveraged lease income of $6 million related
to the termination of the Collins lease.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy Costs</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $7 million for the quarter was primarily due to load increases of $4 million and $3 million from ELCHO and SAESA, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $18 million for the six months was primarily due to load increases of $6 million, $8 million and $5 million from ELCHO, SAESA and Salalah, respectively, offset by a decrease of $1 million from GWF Energy.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operation and Maintenance</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $9 million for the quarter was primarily due to increases of $5 million, $3 million and $2 million from ELCHO, SAESA, and Salalah, respectively, offset by a decrease of $2 million from GWF Energy.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $23 million for the six months was primarily due to increases of $8 million, $5 million, </font><font color=#000000>$4</font><font color=#000000> million and </font><font color=#000000>$3</font><font color=#000000> million from ELCHO, SAESA, Salalah and Electroandes, respectively, offset by a decrease of $4 million from GWF Energy.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $2 million for the quarter was primarily due to increases of $2 million, $1 million and $2 million from ELCHO, SAESA and Salalah, respectively, offset by a decrease of $3 million from GWF Energy.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $7 million for the six months was primarily due to increases of $6 million, $1 million and $5 million from ELCHO, SAESA and Salalah, respectively, offset by a decrease of $5 million from GWF Energy.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income from Equity Method Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $2 million for the quarter was primarily driven by the use of the equity method for GWF Energy in 2004, as discussed above. The increase of $10 million for the six months was primarily driven by $6 million related to GWF Energy and a $4 million increase from Rio Grande Energia S.A. (RGE), a distribution company in Brazil, </font><font color=#000000>primarily due to the write-off of certain deferred assets in 2003</font><font color=#000000>.</font></p>
<p align=center>63</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The </font><font color=#000000>decreases</font><font color=#000000> of $1 million and $4 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, </font><font color=#000000>are</font><font color=#000000> due primarily to the absence of foreign currency transaction gains in 2004 for RGE and SAESA.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increases of $8 million and $5 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, </font><font color=#000000>are</font><font color=#000000> due to a foreign currency transaction loss of $6 million and a loss on extinguishment of debt of $3 million, partially offset by changes in fair value relating to Energy Holdings&#39; derivative instruments of $1 million and $4 million for the quarter and six months, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increases of $14 million and $29 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, </font><font color=#000000>are</font><font color=#000000> due to an increase in non-recourse debt at the project level with higher interest rates, offset in part by the repayment of lower rate debt at Energy Holdings during 2003 and 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The decreases of $12 million and $10 million for the quarter and six months, respectively, </font><font color=#000000>are</font><font color=#000000> primarily due to lower pretax income. In addition, the decrease for the quarter is due to a lower effective rate for Global due to a change in mix of domestic and international earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income</font></b><b><font color=#000000> (Loss) From Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>CPC</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May 21, 2004, Global completed the sale of its interest in CPC for approximately $43 million in cash and recognized a gain on disposal of $5 million. See Note&nbsp;4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes for </font><font color=#000000>additional</font><font color=#000000> information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Technologies</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September 2003, Energy Holdings completed the sale of the remaining companies of Energy Technologies. See Note&nbsp;4. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>To supplement the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements presented in accordance with </font><font color=#000000>accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S.</font><font color=#000000> (GAAP), PSEG and Energy Holdings use the non-GAAP measure of Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; management reviews EBIT internally to evaluate the performance and manage operations and believe that the inclusion of this non-GAAP financial measure provides consistent and comparable measures to help shareholders understand current and future operating results. PSEG and Energy Holdings urge shareholders to carefully review the GAAP financial information included as part of this Quarterly Report.</font></p>
<p align=center>64</p>

<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Total Capital at Risk includes Global&#39;s gross investments, net of equity adjustments, non-recourse debt at the project level and including equity commitment guarantees.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Includes Global&#39;s share of net earnings, including Interest Expense and Income Taxes, for investments accounted for under the equity method of accounting.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Non-recourse interest is Interest Expense </font><font color=#000000>on debt that is non-recourse to Global.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Liquidity'>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&#39;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Cash Flows</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately </font><font color=#000000>$246</font><font color=#000000> million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, as compared to the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003, due primarily to increases of $221 million at PSE&amp;G and $217 million at Energy Holdings, offset by a $207 million decrease at Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $221 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, as compared to the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003, due to higher net income (primarily related to the increase in electric base rates), additional recoveries of regulatory assets and reduced benefit plan contributions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s operating cash flow decreased approximately $207 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, as compared to the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003, due primarily to decreased income</font></p>
<p align=center>65</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>from continuing operations, primarily due to lower sales volumes and higher replacement power and maintenance costs combined with the loss of the MTC revenues, effective August 1, 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operating cash flow increased approximately $217 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, as compared to the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003, due primarily to a tax payment of $115 million made in 2003 related to two terminated leveraged lease transactions at Resources in 2002 and increased tax benefits received from PSEG in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Common Stock Dividends</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 were $0.55 </font><font color=#000000>per share</font><font color=#000000> and totaled approximately $130 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2004 were $1.10 </font><font color=#000000>per share</font><font color=#000000> and totaled approximately $260 million. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&#39;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Debt Covenants</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective credit agreements generally contain customary provisions under which the lenders could refuse to continue to advance funds in the event of a material adverse change in the borrower&#39;s business or financial condition. However, the PSEG and PSE&amp;G credit agreements&#39; material adverse change clauses do not apply when the borrowing is used to repay its commercial paper obligations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As explained in detail below, some of these credit agreements also contain maximum debt-to-equity ratios, minimum cash flow tests and other restrictive covenants and conditions to borrowing. Compliance with applicable financial covenants will depend upon the respective future financial position, level of earnings and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, as to which no assurances can be given. The ratios noted below are for the benefit of the investors of the related securities to which the covenants apply. They are not intended as a financial performance or liquidity measure. The debt underlying the trust preferred securities of PSEG, which is presented in Long-Term Debt in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Interpretation No. 46, &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities
(VIEs)&rdquo; (FIN 46), is not included as debt when calculating these ratios, as provided for in the various credit agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSEG&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of debt (excluding non-recourse project financings, securitization debt and debt underlying preferred securities and including commercial paper and loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio not be more than 70.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, PSEG&#39;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was 58.3%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSE&amp;G&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of long-term debt (excluding securitization debt and long-term debt maturing within one year) to total capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not be more than 65.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, PSE&amp;G&#39;s ratio of long-term debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was 52.9%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, under its First and Refunding Mortgage (Mortgage), PSE&amp;G may issue new First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds against previous additions and improvements, provided that its ratio of</font></p>
<p align=center>66</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>earnings to fixed charges calculated in accordance with its Mortgage is at least 2:1, and/or against retired Mortgage Bonds. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, PSE&amp;G&#39;s Mortgage coverage ratio was 4:1.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in the PSEG/Power joint and several credit facility include a ratio of debt to total capitalization for each specific borrower. For PSEG, the covenant described above in PSEG is applicable. For Power, a debt (excluding non-recourse project financings and including loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization, adjusted to add back the $986 million Basis Adjustment (see Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets), covenant applies. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not exceed 65.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, Power&#39;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was 50.4%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2003, Energy Holdings issued $350 million of Senior Notes which contain financial covenants that include debt incurrence tests consisting of a debt service coverage test and a ratio of consolidated recourse indebtedness to recourse capitalization test. These covenants require that Energy Holdings not incur additional consolidated recourse indebtedness, other than certain permitted indebtedness, unless, on a pro forma basis, giving effect to the incurrence of the additional consolidated recourse indebtedness: (i)&nbsp;the debt service coverage ratio would be at least 2:1; and (ii)&nbsp;the ratio of consolidated recourse indebtedness to recourse capitalization would not exceed 60%. Certain permitted indebtedness, such as permitted refinancings and borrowings are excluded from the requirements under this debt incurrence
test. The provisions of the Senior Notes also restrict Energy Holdings from selling assets with a net book value greater than 10% of its assets in any four consecutive quarters, unless the proceeds are used to reduce debt of Energy Holdings or its subsidiaries or are retained by Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings entered into a $200 million three-year bank revolving credit agreement in October 2003 with a covenant requiring the ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to fixed charges shall not be less than 1.75. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, Energy Holdings&#39; coverage of this covenant was 2.51. Additionally, Energy Holdings must maintain a ratio of net debt to EBITDA not greater than 5.25. As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, Energy Holdings&#39; ratio under this covenant was 3.79. Energy Holdings is a co-borrower under this facility with Global and Resources, which are joint and several obligors. The terms of the agreement include a pledge of Energy Holdings&#39; membership interest in Global, restrictions on the use of proceeds related to material sales of assets and the satisfaction
of certain financial covenants. Cash proceeds from asset sales in excess of 5% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any 12-month period must be used to repay any outstanding amounts under the credit agreement. Cash proceeds in excess of 10% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any 12-month period must be retained by Energy Holdings or used to repay the debt of Energy Holdings, Global or Resources.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Credit Ratings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The current
  ratings of securities of PSEG and its subsidiaries are shown below and reflect
  the respective views of the rating agencies. Any downward revision or withdrawal
  may adversely affect the market price of PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s
  and Energy Holdings&#39; securities and serve to increase those companies&#39;
  cost of capital and limit their access to capital. All ratings have a stable
  outlook unless otherwise noted. (N)&nbsp;denotes a negative outlook and (NW)
  denotes a negative watch. There is no assurance that the ratings will continue
  for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating
  agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances so warrant. Each
  rating given by an agency should be evaluated independently of the other agencies&#39;
  ratings. The ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or
  sell any security.</font></p>
<p align=center>67</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The financial
  objectives for PSEG include improving the credit ratings for each of PSEG and
  Power and maintaining the credit ratings for each of PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings.
  To accomplish this, PSEG expects to improve its funds from operations and interest
  coverage ratios and continue to lower its leverage ratio over the planning period.
  Failure to meet these targets could lead to a lower credit rating.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On April 12, 2004, Fitch downgraded Energy Holdings&#39; Senior Notes rating from BBB- to BB, with a negative outlook.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On July 30, 2004, S&amp;P downgraded PSEG&#39;s and PSE&amp;G&#39;s respective commercial paper ratings from A2 to A3 and placed PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power on negative outlook. Also on July&nbsp;30, 2004, Fitch placed PSEG&#39;s Preferred Securities rating and Power&#39;s Senior Notes rating on negative credit watch.</font></p>

<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font><p></p>

<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Moody&#39;s ratings range from Aaa (highest) to C (lowest) for long-term securities and P-1 (highest) to NP (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>S&amp;P ratings range from AAA (highest) to D (lowest) for long-term securities and A-1 (highest) to D (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Fitch ratings range from AAA (highest) to D (lowest) for long-term securities and F-1 (highest) to D (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Rating for PSE&amp;G Cumulative Preferred Stock without Mandatory Redemption.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=center>68</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Short-Term Liquidity</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2004, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $2.6 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $1.9 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In addition to this amount, PSEG and PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. PSEG had $50 million outstanding and PSE&amp;G had $80 million outstanding under these uncommitted facilities as of June&nbsp;30, 2004. Each of the credit facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>PSEG/Power co-borrower facility.</font></td></tr>

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
